poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Facilitators Offboarding (MDS-001) (MIP41c5-SP5) - March 14, 2022

content.content: MIP41c5-SP5: Facilitators Offboarding (MDS-001)  Preamble MIP41c5-SP#: 5 Author(s): Deimos Contributors: Tags: personnel-xboarding Status: Accepted Date Applied: 2022-02-09 Date Ratified: 2022-03-28 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmV3Lem7?network=mainnet#poll-detail Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip41c5-sp5-facilitator-offboarding/13005   Sentence Summary This subproposal is to offboard the current Facilitators of the MakerDAO Shop.  Specification  Motivation Experiments are great in every organisation. This becomes truer for web3 and truest for MakerDAO. That being said, when an experiment is not killed in time, it becomes a money pit or a missed opportunity. Several strong reasons indicate that this is a good time to release this team from their duties:  Lack of Quality This point might be hard to qualify or quantify when a shop is up and running. Ultimately it comes down to the metrics. The meme Wizard has done much better things and there are groups interested in making swag great again.  Lack of Service It has been reported by several community members that the site has been down for weeks, which is unacceptable at any point in time after 1997.  Lack of Accountability This team promised 50% of the revenue of the shop, and they have vested approximately 0 Dai to the Protocol. We probably don’t care that much, but not delivering on a promise should have some consequences. Reputation?  Conclusion After wasting everyone’s time and delivering zero results --both in terms of branding or monetary-- we need to remove this team to allow for space so that other teams can grow into it. This team representing Maker is enough to discourage new talent from joining the DAO. The quality bar needs to be several miles higher.  Core Unit ID MDS-001
content.GPT-summary: The post is a subproposal explaining the offboarding of the current Facilitators of the MakerDAO Shop due to lack of quality, service, and accountability. The author provides reasons for why it is necessary to remove the team and allow other teams to grow into the space. The post also includes the Core Unit ID and relevant dates. A 3rd party gives entirely negative feedback on the proposal, while another gives constructive criticism.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
None

content.content: Deimos, completely understand the frustration and motive behind your post. The unfortunate reality is that, for a number of reasons, the shop has not functioned the way we (or the community) had hoped. We accept responsibility for that and would like to share a recommendation on how to move forward. But first, some context. Coulter and I made the proposal to run the shop because we are enthusiastic supporters of Maker and wanted to continue to contribute to the project even after our roles in the Foundation were decentralized. While conceptually simple, the store was much more complicated to pull together in practice than either of us expected, especially from a legal perspective. Luckily, none of the issues were insurmountable, but they did result in time delays and, eventually, disruption in service. Let’s talk about money. The store made $2115.82 and .1806ETH (from crypto payments) in profit in the time it was functional and, per the agreement 50% of that belongs to Maker. We have not shared that money yet as we do not have a place to send it. Once we have the best accounts for the project we will initiate the transfer ASAP. Now, our recommendation. Swag makes people happy. @aburban90  is the embodiment of happiness in the Maker Community. We’ve worked with him multiple times to get him the swag he needs for his CU. We suggest folding the store into the Strategic Happiness core unit, if Andrew is up for it. Andrew is passionate about the project and has poured his heart and soul into creating and sharing fantastic swag that drives engagement and happiness. We think it’s a perfect fit. This is, as always, a call for the community to make, but we think this is the best option as it wouldn’t require new proposals/votes etc… we can just transfer everything to him if the community wishes.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party extending to proposal
None of the topics listed match

content.content: MakerMikeP:  While conceptually simple, the store was much more complicated to pull together in practice than either of us expected, especially from a legal perspective. Luckily, none of the issues were insurmountable, but they did result in time delays and,   Based on these challenges, It sounds like the shop experiment may not be a good fit. It may be best to continue to keep the shop off. SHCU is not a professional CU nor does not suggest itself to be (nor does it desire to be, but burban can correct here if he wants to be held accountable to the DAO for swag drops and online shop tech performance). This initiative was sold to the DAO as independently-managed initiative with no out of pocket cost delivering money to the DAO without effort or headache. It seems appropriate the Shop Core unit simply keep the ether and cash profits and just unwind. It can be taken over when a proper marketing core unit comes online. Right now the rep of our shop has taken a hit for no gain. Rolling it up into a new chimera sounds like another uncertain and risky venture for little gain trading on the Maker brand.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Deimos:  After wasting everyone’s time and delivering zero results --both in terms of branding or monetary-- we need to remove this team to allow for space so that other teams can grow into it. This team representing Maker is enough to discourage new talent from joining the DAO. The quality bar needs to be several miles higher.   Just pointing out that this justification seems pointlessly hostile, I worry that this is exacerbated by anons on a warpath against core units. You get what you pay for, and the DAO didn’t pay anything for the shop. It’s possible to acknowledge that this isn’t working out without casting these sorts of aspersions.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Just pointing out that this justification seems pointlessly hostile, I worry that this is exacerbated by anons on a warpath against core units. You get what you pay for, and the DAO didn’t pay anything for the shop. It’s possible to acknowledge that this isn’t working out without casting these sorts of aspersions.  Agreed!  Great points!  This post seems pointlessly hostile and aggressive.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: An alternate approach to letting angry anons dictate the direction of the DAO might be to give these guys a real budget so that they can focus on putting real effort into this project instead of treating it like the side project it is. (If they’re up for it.) It seems like the shop was/is a passion project, and they had ongoing issues with IP arrangements with the Dai Foundation that set them back early on. The solutions the DAO should focus around should probably include giving them the resources they need to succeed instead of stabbing them in the back with a disposable identity. Coulter and Mike have been around longer than I have, and I don’t think it’s right to do them like this. They have community goodwill and reputational stake here and have given a lot of themselves to the DAO over the last few years. If anyone can pull off the shop, it’s them, but it’s easier to destroy than to help grow, I guess. No alternative shop provider has been proffered here, so the idea that others are waiting in the wings to create a shop but are only hindered by the fact that there’s already a shop core unit seems pretty speculative. I’d argue, on the other hand, that this sort of MIP proposal does more to harm morale in every other core unit than good that can possibly be done by sniping longtime Maker community members from unpaid roles.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: MakerMikeP:  The unfortunate reality is that, for a number of reasons, the shop has not functioned the way we (or the community) had hoped.   I don’t think you or anyone else should be offended in this case. Rather, it should be about asking first if something is not clear. However, I do think it was a mistake on your part to completely lack communication . It has been a long time since you last posted here (sorry if I missed something), essentially no information has been revealed. From the outside, it may have looked like you had quit the project, which may have added to the frustration of some people. What was the main problem?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: There’s no one taking offense here. Neither myself nor @MakerMikeP wants this to be drawn into some dramatic thread. I’d prefer posts about the tone of anons and the best way to offboard CUs takes place elsewhere and we focus simply on what the next steps are for the store. To your other points, we could have been more active in the forums, sure. Though when questions would come up in the discord, I felt they were answered in a timely manner. As mentioned there – and I’ll keep this vague to avoid pointing any fingers – the decentralized servers we chose and support for the store disappeared quickly after the store was live. There were some legal/IP issues early on but those were sorted. Again, all Mike and I care about is the next steps. Transferring to @aburban90 (who I believe is traveling currently and thus unable to chime in) felt like a good solution for all parties. If the community would rather take proposals from others, that’s completely fine with us.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Agreed on the solution oriented frame. The natural course may be to simply leave the shop off. It hasn’t been live for months which is unfortunate but a couple more months is still do-able. It doesn’t sound like Burban wants to take this over and foisting it onto him in its current state is probably not fair either. At the same time, the DAO may not ready to cut a check for a shop CU when there are new marketing CUs coming online through SES. Happy to be proven wrong but not sure what the other responsible alternatives are here.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: Coulter:  There’s no one taking offense here. Neither myself nor @MakerMikeP wants this to be drawn into some dramatic thread.   I think I phrased it wrong.  I meant to say that no one should immediately make a proposal to offboarding, if the background is unknown. That is not the way to go. If someone feels things are not going well, then ask for information first, like “Hey guys, we haven’t heard from you in a long time, what’s going on behind the scenes?”.

content.content: As I said previously, I answered in discord and said we could have been more active in the forums for the store. My activity as a whole in the forums is minimum because I didn’t want to meddle in the Foundation dissolution process in any way. Again, Mike and I have proposed solutions. The community can take it from here.

content.content: I’m pretty honored to be considered. Right now, busy in Denver. Let me return to topic after 25th?

Do you think you would be able to put together a short post-mortem? Even if there is a hand-off between core units, the community needs to know what they are getting into now. We are all smarter based on the challenges you faced if we can document them. Regardless of whether it is a transfer or an unwinding, a new MIP set with an appropriate budget with transparent management is probably needed to make sure we can deliver and avoid further issue to MakerDAO (to McMichael’s point). The original MIP was early on and a reasonable shot in the dark and blind faith. The DAO is much further along in its due diligence WRT proposals. The best way to proceed would be to demonstrate actual oversight or analysis of what it would take to deliver on a shop to MakerDAO standards. Also, it is implied in your post you and Mike are stepping down from the core unit regardless? @MakerMikeP  If so, do you think you could just make that clear, it would make this facilitator offboarding thread and the accompanying core unit thread irrelevant. It would also move this forward to a different (more productive) stage.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving entirely negative feedback on proposal

content.content: brianmcmichael:  An alternate approach to letting angry anons dictate the direction of the DAO might be to give these guys a real budget so that they can focus on putting real effort into this project instead of treating it like the side project it is. (If they’re up for it.)   Just want to be clear that angry anon’s don’t dictate the direction of the DAO - even if it might sometimes feel like it - the outcome of votes do. Sometimes having proposals that we don’t agree with is an unavoidable outcome of having the proposal process open to anyone. It doesn’t mean that these proposals are what the DAO actually wants as a whole. Proposals are one of the mechanisms through which we collectively find out what the DAO wants as a whole.     brianmcmichael:  Just pointing out that this justification seems pointlessly hostile, I worry that this is exacerbated by anons on a warpath against core units. You get what you pay for, and the DAO didn’t pay anything for the shop. It’s possible to acknowledge that this isn’t working out without casting these sorts of aspersions.   Totally agree with this, though, and I would encourage @Deimos to keep this in mind in the future.     Puzzler:  Perhaps needs a new discussion, but why does maker never ask for bidding?   Anyone is able to do this through MIP13. I’m not 100% sure why it isn’t utilized more. But I suspect part of it is lack of familiarity with the MIP, and because it’s a moderate amount of effort to make a proposal.

brianmcmichael:  and they had ongoing issues with IP arrangements with the Dai Foundation that set them back early on   I missed this as we weren’t tagged. Dai Foundation is there to protect the the intangible assets of MakerDAO and not provide specific favors outside what Maker Governance decides. Our aim is to do this with as little friction as possible, so we certainly don’t want to delay anything that goes to support the DAO. I am not aware of “issues” with Dai Foundation from a DAO point of view or how Dai Foundation can have had any share in how the Maker Shop has performed. Can you provide links to description of the issues/additional context such that Dai Foundation can perform a proper post mortem?

content.content: yeah offboard it. Hate to be callus, but I’d be willing to bet no one in this thread can honestly say they own a Wells Fargo, BoA, JPM Chase, or Federal Reserve t shirt. Hell even a bitcoin shirt is something I’ve never seen in public, but given the group I’m speaking to i won’t make any wagers on that. Based on that, I don’t see any reason to believe there would be any material demand for a MKR / DAI one. Seems like a waste of money/effort to me. Kill it.

content.content: Seriously. Go to any Ethereum conference and you’ll see Maker shirts everywhere. That’s what we want.
Do you think that they were all bought through the shop or are most of them just reprints?
Probably most people got their shirts at different conferences and the like (or at Goodwill or wherever). Who knows?

In summary, it seems appropriate to unwind it for now under the current MIP that offers no resources or support to the team, let the CU keep the negligible revenue, and then decide how Maker wants to restart moving forward, if at all, be that with a presently existing core unit or another route. It would still be very appreciated if @coulter could find some time to put together a short post-mortem on what the challenges were and how we could avoid repeating them in the future. Such a review would honor the effort he and Mike invested, even if the shop did not come to fruition in the way they had hoped.
